'created_at': '2022-03-11T13:41:13Z', 'updated_at': '2022-04-22T14:10:24Z', 'closed_at': '2022-04-22T14:10:24Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '**Description:** The [NavigationView](https://developer.android.com/reference/com/google/android/material/navigation/NavigationView) class fails to inflate after upgrading the Material Components library from version `1.4.0` to `1.5.0+`.

**Expected behavior:** The [NavigationView](https://developer.android.com/reference/com/google/android/material/navigation/NavigationView) class inflates with versions `1.5.0+` like it does with versions `1.4.0` and earlier.

**Android API version:** My project's `compileSdkVersion` and `targetSdkVersion` values are set to 31.

**Material Library version:** `1.5.0+` (including `1.6.0-alpha03`)

**Device:** Reproduced on an Android 12 emulator and an Android 9 device.

**Cause:** Set the [NavigationView](https://developer.android.com/reference/com/google/android/material/navigation/NavigationView)'s `app:itemIconTint` value to a style attribute like `"?android:attr/textColorSecondary"` and assign an unnamed color resource to the `android:textColorSecondary` style value, as follows:

```
<style name="AppTheme" parent="Theme.MaterialComponents.Light.NoActionBar">
    <item name="android:textColorSecondary">#000000</item>
</style>
```', 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/material-components/material-components-android/issues/2595/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'timeline_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/material-components/material-components-android/issues/2595/timeline', 'performed_via_github_app': None}}

'updated_at': '2022-04-22T14:08:49Z', 'closed_at': '2022-04-22T14:08:49Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '**Description:** 
When using RangeSlider with Huawei Android 9 phones the label does not disappear completely after adjusting. Parts of the label still remain on the screen.

**Expected behavior:** 
Label is disappearing

**Source code:** 
```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
    xmlns:app="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res-auto"
    xmlns:tools="http://schemas.android.com/tools"
    android:layout_width="match_parent"
    android:layout_height="match_parent"
    android:paddingTop="80dp"
    tools:context=".MainActivity">

    <com.google.android.material.slider.RangeSlider
        android:id="@+id/amountSlider"
        android:layout_width="match_parent"
        android:layout_height="wrap_content"
        android:stepSize="1"
        android:valueFrom="0.0"
        android:valueTo="100.0"
        app:values="@array/initial_slider_values"
        tools:ignore="MissingConstraints" />

</androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout>
```

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/72196651/161275659-6fb550ac-eb45-4497-b7d8-b0d76aca45ea.png)


**Android API version:** 31

**Material Library version:** 1.5.0 (also tried 1.6.0-beta01)

**Device:** Huawei P20 Pro, Android 9', 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/material-components/material-components-android/issues/2624/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'timeline_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/material-components/material-components-android/issues/2624/timeline', 'performed_via_github_app': None}}

'updated_at': '2022-04-22T14:08:29Z', 'closed_at': '2022-04-22T14:08:28Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': "**Description:** 

This issue is somewhat minor since it only affects testing, but when doing screenshot testing and manual screenshot reviews for content and layout correctness by non-devs it becomes a bit more of an issue.

When opening the Material Date Picker inside a fragment scenario test (overriding the theme with the app's theme), the selected date text is incorrectly aligned. This only occurs in fragment scenario tests and not when the app is run normally. It is also the only difference I can spot between the app theme running in an app versus the same app theme running in a fragment scenario.

Screenshot from layout inspector showing border, from what I can tell the view appears to be missing its `paddingTop` property when run in a fragment scenario test:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1129772/103495978-47ad7180-4e88-11eb-8935-71ba61bd5a33.png)

**Expected behavior:** 

Calendar should have the correct text alignment
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1129772/103496128-c7d3d700-4e88-11eb-84b4-5a1653b9d731.png)

**Android API version:** 29

**Material Library version:** 1.3.0-alpha04

**Device:** Samsung Galaxy S10, though I've seen it occur on other devices and in the emulator
", 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/material-components/material-components-android/issues/1960/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'timeline_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/material-components/material-components-android/issues/1960/timeline', 'performed_via_github_app': None}}

'updated_at': '2022-04-22T14:07:04Z', 'closed_at': '2022-04-22T14:07:03Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '**Description:** 
`MaterialShapeDrawable` is used everywhere as background drawable to support material shapes and fake shadows, its "elevation" is important as it seems to affect its color/shade, i.e. becoming brighter with increased elevation on a dark theme.

But lots of components have no default elevation, ignores any `app:elevation` attribute, or incorrectly gets it from some other view using `ViewCompat.getElevation()` which always returns zero on pre-Lollipop devices.

This has major consequences on pre-Lollipop, especially when using a dark theme, e.g. DayNight, where the `AppBarLayout` and dialog backgrounds become black at zero elevation. For screenshorts, see my related issue report: https://issuetracker.google.com/issues/142127327

`AppBarLayout` rely on a `StateListAnimator` which is only available/set on Lollipop:
https://github.com/material-components/material-components-android/blob/release-1.1/lib/java/com/google/android/material/appbar/AppBarLayout.java#L238

`MaterialAlertDialogBuilder` and `MaterialDatePicker` get their elevation from decorView, which is always zero on pre-Lollipop:
https://github.com/material-components/material-components-android/blob/release-1.1/lib/java/com/google/android/material/dialog/MaterialAlertDialogBuilder.java#L147
https://github.com/material-components/material-components-android/blob/release-1.1/lib/java/com/google/android/material/datepicker/MaterialDatePicker.java#L169

Some components like `NavigationView` do the right thing, honoring `app:elevation` attribute, and thus work as expected:
https://github.com/material-components/material-components-android/blob/master/lib/java/com/google/android/material/navigation/NavigationView.java#L155

More components are probably affected by this bug/oversight. It seems few components have been properly tested on pre-Lollipop with a dark theme.

**Expected behavior:**
Toolbars and dialogs having the same/similar colors both pre and post Lollipop. On pre-Lollipop i'd expect the components to get (fallback) elevation from their respective theme/style, i.e. an `app:elevation` attribute, or in some other way,

**Android API version:**
Android 4.0 thru 4.4

**Material Library version:** 
com.google.android.material:material:1.1.0-beta01

**Device:**

<com.google.android.material.textfield.TextInputLayout
            android:layout_width="match_parent"
            android:layout_height="0dp"
            android:id="@+id/username"
            app:layout_constraintTop_toTopOf="parent"
            app:layout_constraintStart_toStartOf="parent"
            app:layout_constraintBottom_toTopOf="@+id/password"
            app:layout_constraintVertical_chainStyle="spread_inside"
            app:layout_constraintHeight_default="percent"
            app:layout_constraintHeight_percent="0.2"
            android:hint="ggggggggggggggggg"
            android:background="@color/primaryColor"
            app:boxStrokeColor="@color/secondaryDarkColor"
            app:boxStrokeWidth="10px">
            <com.google.android.material.textfield.TextInputEditText
                android:layout_width="match_parent"
                android:layout_height="wrap_content"
                />
        </com.google.android.material.textfield.TextInputLayout>
```

This is part of a constrained layout, and I have the same issue even if I set the `height` of `Textinputedittext` to `match_parent`; the result is [this](https://i.stack.imgur.com/Jv6uX.png)

'comments': 13, 'created_at': '2019-12-19T17:17:52Z', 'updated_at': '2022-04-20T13:35:54Z', 'closed_at': '2022-04-14T20:26:02Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '**Description:** When using a MaterialButton with fixed width and fixed number of text lines, I tried to find a way to deal with dynamic button text that could be too long for the button size. When the text is too long for the button the words that don't fit will simply not be displayed by default, thus not indicating that there are words missing. When setting "ellipsize" to "end" the three dots get displayed, but the beginning of the text will be cut off in some situations.

**Steps to reproduce:** Check out and run this sample project: [https://github.com/geworfener/MaterialButtonEllipsizeBug](url)

Alternatively:
1. Create a new Android project with a single activity.
2. Add material lib and set material theme.
3. Use the following activity layout:
```<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
    xmlns:app="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res-auto"
    xmlns:tools="http://schemas.android.com/tools"
    android:layout_width="match_parent"
    android:layout_height="match_parent"
    tools:context=".MainActivity">

    <com.google.android.material.button.MaterialButton
        android:layout_width="128dp"
        android:layout_height="wrap_content"
        android:maxLines="2"
        android:ellipsize="end"
        android:text="Hello world, this is a long text!"
        app:layout_constraintBottom_toBottomOf="parent"
        app:layout_constraintLeft_toLeftOf="parent"
        app:layout_constraintRight_toRightOf="parent"
        app:layout_constraintTop_toTopOf="parent" />

</androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout>
```

**Actual behavior:** 

The first letter of the second text line gets cut off.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6763984/71192737-28e23a00-2289-11ea-933e-08fe8950997b.png)


**Expected behavior:** All words of the text are displayed fully.

**Android API version:** 28

**Material Library version:** 1.1.0-beta02, 1.2.0-alpha02

**Device:** Pixel 3a XL

'2022-04-19T18:53:04Z', 'closed_at': '2022-04-18T15:12:31Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '**Description:** 
The implementation with Chip in Material 3 is not working after following the [documentation](https://m3.material.io/components/chips/implementation)

**Expected behavior:** 
Should apply the styling based on what was stated in the documentation.

**Source code:** 

Not working, incorrect color.
```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<resources>
    <!-- Chip style on both light and night mode -->
    <style name="AppChip" parent="Widget.Material3.Chip.Input">
        <item name="closeIconVisible">false</item>
        <item name="checkedIconVisible">false</item>
        <item name="materialThemeOverlay">@style/ThemeOverlay.App.Chip</item>
        <item name="shapeAppearanceOverlay">@style/ShapeAppearance.App.SmallComponent</item>
    </style>
    <style name="ThemeOverlay.App.Chip" parent="">
        <item name="colorOnSurfaceVariant">@color/chip_state_list</item>
        <item name="colorOnSurface">@color/background_color_chip_state_list</item>
    </style>
</resources>
```

Working correct color
```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<resources>
    <!-- Chip style on both light and night mode -->
    <style name="AppChip" parent="Widget.Material3.Chip.Input">
        <item name="closeIconVisible">false</item>
        <item name="checkedIconVisible">false</item>
        <item name="android:textColor">@color/chip_state_list</item>
        <item name="chipStrokeColor">@android:color/transparent</item>
        <item name="chipBackgroundColor">@color/background_color_chip_state_list</item>
        <item name="shapeAppearanceOverlay">@style/ShapeAppearance.App.SmallComponent</item>
    </style>
    <!--TODO theme overlay-->
</resources>
```

Usage in main theme
`<item name="chipStyle">@style/AppChip</item>`

**Android API version:** SDK 21

**Material Library version:** 1.6.0-beta-01

**Device:** Samsung J1

Is it just me or the Material 3 components and its documentations are not yet finish or finalize? I keep having this issue where the documentation and the behavior is not correct.

{'push_id': 9662950841, 'size': 1, 'distinct_size': 1, 'ref': 'refs/heads/master', 'head': '45b99f603e377e978d7a73cdfee10b50ed83ff43', 'before': 'db167635e49e75522c808aaf1caf4068002da3b3', 'commits': [{'sha': '45b99f603e377e978d7a73cdfee10b50ed83ff43', 'author': {'email': 'conradchen@google.com', 'name': 'conradchen'}, 'message': "[Button] Fix the issue that button state is not updated

On Lollipop, when first assigned as View's background, RippleDrawable won't/can't propagate states to its content drawable. This causes the issue that the state relevant features like stroke colors are not correctly updated when the background is recreated. Explicitly assigns states to the content drawable to fix the issue.

Resolves https://github.com/material-components/material-components-android/issues/1422

PiperOrigin-RevId: 442676637", 'distinct': True, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/material-components/material-components-android/commits/45b99f603e377e978d7a73cdfee10b50ed83ff43'}]}

'2022-04-19T14:58:42Z', 'closed_at': '2022-04-19T14:58:42Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '**Description:**
I have a MaterialButtonToggleGroup with a three buttons, all with the outline style. The outlines on the outer buttons are blurred, while the outline of the button in middle isn't

**Expected behavior:**
Please see https://github.com/openhab/openhab-android/issues/1615#issuecomment-543765157 for a photo of this issue. It seems that is happens only on low dpi devices.

Please see https://github.com/openhab/openhab-android/issues/1615#issuecomment-543785569 for a possible explanation for this bug:

> My guess would be rounding issues on hdpi devices, since that's the only density which yields a non-integer dp-to-px ratio (1.5 to be precise). This means e.g. 1dp becomes 1.5px, which can be displayed as 1px (too thin) or 2px (too wide).

**Source code:**
I can reproduce this issue with https://github.com/ricknout/android-mdc-theming, master at 576d0f2e02a599ccbc00b7bc2ee04709f962111a and the following diff:
````diff
diff --git a/app/src/main/res/values/styles_button.xml b/app/src/main/res/values/styles_button.xml
index a6ac8df..a52ccfe 100644
--- a/app/src/main/res/values/styles_button.xml
+++ b/app/src/main/res/values/styles_button.xml
@@ -22,10 +22,6 @@
         <item name="textAppearanceButton">@style/AppTextAppearance.Button</item>
         <item name="fontFamily">@font/roboto_mono</item>
         <item name="android:fontFamily">@font/roboto_mono</item>
-        <!-- Global shape attributes -->
-        <item name="shapeAppearanceSmallComponent">@style/AppShapeAppearance.SmallComponent</item>
-        <item name="shapeAppearanceMediumComponent">@style/AppShapeAppearance.MediumComponent</item>
-        <item name="shapeAppearanceLargeComponent">@style/AppShapeAppearance.LargeComponent</item>
         <!-- Button widget style attributes -->
         <item name="materialButtonStyle">@style/AppButton2</item>
         <item name="materialButtonOutlinedStyle">@style/AppOutlinedButton</item>
diff --git a/build.gradle b/build.gradle
index 18bd726..9464d40 100644
--- a/build.gradle
+++ b/build.gradle
@@ -1,5 +1,5 @@
 buildscript {
-    ext.android_gradle_plugin_version = '4.0.0-rc01'
+    ext.android_gradle_plugin_version = '4.0.0'
     ext.kotlin_version = '1.3.72'
     ext.androidx_core_version = "1.3.0-rc01"
     ext.androidx_appcompat_version = "1.2.0-beta01"

````

Without the patch the outlines of all buttons are blurred.

**Android API version:**
At least on Android 5.1.1 and 7.1.2

**Material Library version:**
1.3.0-alpha01

**Device:**

- Samsung Galaxy Tab PT-P7500
- [Fire 7 Tablet](https://www.amazon.com/Fire-Tablet-7/dp/B07FKR6KXF)

**Source code:** 

Not working, incorrect color.
```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<resources>
    <!-- Chip style on both light and night mode -->
    <style name="AppChip" parent="Widget.Material3.Chip.Input">
        <item name="closeIconVisible">false</item>
        <item name="checkedIconVisible">false</item>
        <item name="materialThemeOverlay">@style/ThemeOverlay.App.Chip</item>
        <item name="shapeAppearanceOverlay">@style/ShapeAppearance.App.SmallComponent</item>
    </style>
    <style name="ThemeOverlay.App.Chip" parent="">
        <item name="colorOnSurfaceVariant">@color/chip_state_list</item>
        <item name="colorOnSurface">@color/background_color_chip_state_list</item>
    </style>
</resources>
```

Working correct color
```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<resources>
    <!-- Chip style on both light and night mode -->
    <style name="AppChip" parent="Widget.Material3.Chip.Input">
        <item name="closeIconVisible">false</item>
        <item name="checkedIconVisible">false</item>
        <item name="android:textColor">@color/chip_state_list</item>
        <item name="chipStrokeColor">@android:color/transparent</item>
        <item name="chipBackgroundColor">@color/background_color_chip_state_list</item>
        <item name="shapeAppearanceOverlay">@style/ShapeAppearance.App.SmallComponent</item>
    </style>
    <!--TODO theme overlay-->
</resources>
```

Usage in main theme
`<item name="chipStyle">@style/AppChip</item>`

**Android API version:** SDK 21

**Material Library version:** 1.6.0-beta-01

**Device:** Samsung J1

Is it just me or the Material 3 components and its documentations are not yet finish or finalize? I keep having this issue where the documentation and the behavior is not correct.

{'push_id': 9653725560, 'size': 1, 'distinct_size': 1, 'ref': 'refs/heads/master', 'head': '5b9f27aad0bb185261d6e400274a416953755d74', 'before': '788866e4483621e2222f649e617ee95f7aa9caa6', 'commits': [{'sha': '5b9f27aad0bb185261d6e400274a416953755d74', 'author': {'email': 'conradchen@google.com', 'name': 'conradchen'}, 'message': '[SnackBar] Make dismiss direction the same as swipe direction

In SwipeDismissBehavior, when dismissing views according to the horizontal velocity instead of position delta, we would still using position delta to decide the dismissing direction, which, unfortunately, makes the view always be dismissed from left to right because of the "less than" logic we are using doesn't really take the equaling case into account. Fixes this by using the velocity direction to dismiss the view instead.

Resolves https://github.com/material-components/material-components-android/issues/1868

PiperOrigin-RevId: 442553318', 'distinct': True, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/material-components/material-components-android/commits/5b9f27aad0bb185261d6e400274a416953755d74'}]}

'https://api.github.com/users/drchen/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}], 'milestone': None, 'comments': 0, 'created_at': '2020-06-18T17:43:33Z', 'updated_at': '2022-04-18T16:03:13Z', 'closed_at': None, 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '**Description:**
I have a MaterialButtonToggleGroup with a three buttons, all with the outline style. The outlines on the outer buttons are blurred, while the outline of the button in middle isn't

**Expected behavior:**
Please see https://github.com/openhab/openhab-android/issues/1615#issuecomment-543765157 for a photo of this issue. It seems that is happens only on low dpi devices.

Please see https://github.com/openhab/openhab-android/issues/1615#issuecomment-543785569 for a possible explanation for this bug:

> My guess would be rounding issues on hdpi devices, since that's the only density which yields a non-integer dp-to-px ratio (1.5 to be precise). This means e.g. 1dp becomes 1.5px, which can be displayed as 1px (too thin) or 2px (too wide).

**Source code:**
I can reproduce this issue with https://github.com/ricknout/android-mdc-theming, master at 576d0f2e02a599ccbc00b7bc2ee04709f962111a and the following diff:
````diff
diff --git a/app/src/main/res/values/styles_button.xml b/app/src/main/res/values/styles_button.xml
index a6ac8df..a52ccfe 100644
--- a/app/src/main/res/values/styles_button.xml
+++ b/app/src/main/res/values/styles_button.xml
@@ -22,10 +22,6 @@
         <item name="textAppearanceButton">@style/AppTextAppearance.Button</item>
         <item name="fontFamily">@font/roboto_mono</item>
         <item name="android:fontFamily">@font/roboto_mono</item>
-        <!-- Global shape attributes -->
-        <item name="shapeAppearanceSmallComponent">@style/AppShapeAppearance.SmallComponent</item>
-        <item name="shapeAppearanceMediumComponent">@style/AppShapeAppearance.MediumComponent</item>
-        <item name="shapeAppearanceLargeComponent">@style/AppShapeAppearance.LargeComponent</item>
         <!-- Button widget style attributes -->
         <item name="materialButtonStyle">@style/AppButton2</item>
         <item name="materialButtonOutlinedStyle">@style/AppOutlinedButton</item>
diff --git a/build.gradle b/build.gradle
index 18bd726..9464d40 100644
--- a/build.gradle
+++ b/build.gradle
@@ -1,5 +1,5 @@
 buildscript {
-    ext.android_gradle_plugin_version = '4.0.0-rc01'
+    ext.android_gradle_plugin_version = '4.0.0'
     ext.kotlin_version = '1.3.72'
     ext.androidx_core_version = "1.3.0-rc01"
     ext.androidx_appcompat_version = "1.2.0-beta01"

````

Without the patch the outlines of all buttons are blurred.

**Android API version:**
At least on Android 5.1.1 and 7.1.2

**Material Library version:**
1.3.0-alpha01

**Device:**

- Samsung Galaxy Tab PT-P7500
- [Fire 7 Tablet](https://www.amazon.com/Fire-Tablet-7/dp/B07FKR6KXF)

'2022-04-18T16:03:13Z', 'updated_at': '2022-04-18T16:03:13Z', 'author_association': 'CONTRIBUTOR', 'body': 'I think it's actually caused by RippleDrawable implementation of Lollipop doesn't correctly propagate drawable state when view is being attached (or under certain corner situations). So buttons in a toggle group look as in "disabled" state, and that's why the outlines are blurred. 

Are you sure it also happen on Android 7? I can only reproduce this on Android 5/5.1.

'2022-04-18T15:12:31Z', 'closed_at': '2022-04-18T15:12:31Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '**Description:** 
The implementation with Chip in Material 3 is not working after following the [documentation](https://m3.material.io/components/chips/implementation)

**Expected behavior:** 
Should apply the styling based on what was stated in the documentation.

**Source code:** 

Not working, incorrect color.
```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<resources>
    <!-- Chip style on both light and night mode -->
    <style name="AppChip" parent="Widget.Material3.Chip.Input">
        <item name="closeIconVisible">false</item>
        <item name="checkedIconVisible">false</item>
        <item name="materialThemeOverlay">@style/ThemeOverlay.App.Chip</item>
        <item name="shapeAppearanceOverlay">@style/ShapeAppearance.App.SmallComponent</item>
    </style>
    <style name="ThemeOverlay.App.Chip" parent="">
        <item name="colorOnSurfaceVariant">@color/chip_state_list</item>
        <item name="colorOnSurface">@color/background_color_chip_state_list</item>
    </style>
</resources>
```

Working correct color
```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<resources>
    <!-- Chip style on both light and night mode -->
    <style name="AppChip" parent="Widget.Material3.Chip.Input">
        <item name="closeIconVisible">false</item>
        <item name="checkedIconVisible">false</item>
        <item name="android:textColor">@color/chip_state_list</item>
        <item name="chipStrokeColor">@android:color/transparent</item>
        <item name="chipBackgroundColor">@color/background_color_chip_state_list</item>
        <item name="shapeAppearanceOverlay">@style/ShapeAppearance.App.SmallComponent</item>
    </style>
    <!--TODO theme overlay-->
</resources>
```

Usage in main theme
`<item name="chipStyle">@style/AppChip</item>`

**Android API version:** SDK 21

**Material Library version:** 1.6.0-beta-01

**Device:** Samsung J1

Is it just me or the Material 3 components and its documentations are not yet finish or finalize? I keep having this issue where the documentation and the behavior is not correct.

None, 'body': '**Description:** TextInputLayout + windowLayoutInDisplayCutoutMode (drawing on both sides of notch)
results in behaviour below

![fitSystemWindowsTrueFalse](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30546097/88140991-accb1e80-cbea-11ea-8955-b85f2c86b63c.png)

Second screen is fitSystemWindows set to true
Third screen is what it looks as xml Layout which is perfectly what first screen is achieving.

https://github.com/andrzejbogacz/material_design_bug

**Android API version:** Min api 27

**Material Library version:** any stable + beta + alpha (all)

**Device:** any with notch, tested with both emulators and real device

If with the same settings, but replacing TextInputLayout with a plain LinearLayout and adding some views programmatically into it, will it work correctly? It looks more like caused by a strange combination of ConstraintLayout settings + Notch + System window settings.

I'll close the issue as infeasible.

'2020-06-07T03:03:30Z', 'updated_at': '2022-04-15T20:32:07Z', 'closed_at': '2022-04-15T20:32:07Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '**Description:** The `TextInputLayout` falls down `12dp` when floating label is disabled using `app:hintEnabled="false"` and when placed in a LinearLayout.

**Screenshot** -
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13934280/83959277-a2ea9780-a898-11ea-8400-6ffc34d10d1f.png)


**Expected behavior:**  `TextInputLayout` on the left has Floating Label disabled by using `app:hintEnabled=false` and `TextInputLayout` on the right has Floating Label Enabled.
The left one falls down, when it should not and stay aligned with the right one.
Error is enabled in both the Fields.

**Source code:** 
```
<LinearLayout
        android:layout_width="match_parent"
        android:layout_height="wrap_content"
        android:orientation="horizontal" >

        <com.google.android.material.textfield.TextInputLayout
            style="@style/Widget.MaterialComponents.TextInputLayout.FilledBox"
            android:layout_width="200dp"
            android:layout_height="wrap_content"
            app:errorEnabled="true"
            app:hintEnabled="false" >

            <com.google.android.material.textfield.TextInputEditText
                android:layout_width="match_parent"
                android:layout_height="wrap_content"
                android:hint="Floating Label/Hint Disabled" />

        </com.google.android.material.textfield.TextInputLayout>

        <com.google.android.material.textfield.TextInputLayout
            style="@style/Widget.MaterialComponents.TextInputLayout.FilledBox"
            android:layout_width="200dp"
            android:layout_height="wrap_content"
            app:errorEnabled="true"
            android:hint="Floating Label/Hint Enabled" >

            <com.google.android.material.textfield.TextInputEditText
                android:layout_width="match_parent"
                android:layout_height="wrap_content" />

        </com.google.android.material.textfield.TextInputLayout>
</LinearLayout>
```

**Android API version:** 28

**Material Library version:** `implementation 'com.google.android.material:material:1.1.0'`

**Device:** Android Studio Preview Window and Redmi 4X (India)

**Workaround:** If I offset the top margin by 12 dp - `android:marginTop="-12dp"`, it aligns with right one. '2020-02-19T16:03:06Z', 'updated_at': '2022-04-15T20:28:17Z', 'closed_at': None, 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': 'During testing of Accessibility, tests on EditText in TextInputLayout fail with "View is missing speakable text needed for a screen reader". A similar issue is described here, but the proposed solutions with XML parameters do not help. Tested on library versions 1.1.0 and 1.2.0-alpha04.

Layout part:

```xml
<com.google.android.material.textfield.TextInputLayout
    android:id="@+id/login_email_address"
    android:layout_width="0dp"
    android:layout_height="wrap_content"
    android:layout_marginTop="@dimen/padding_l"
    android:layout_marginLeft="@dimen/padding_l"
    android:layout_marginStart="@dimen/padding_l"
    android:layout_marginRight="@dimen/padding_l"
    android:layout_marginEnd="@dimen/padding_l"
    android:labelFor="@id/login_email_address_edit_text"
    android:accessibilityHeading="true"
    android:contentDescription="@string/login_email_address"
    app:layout_constraintTop_toBottomOf="@id/login_error_message"
    app:layout_constraintLeft_toLeftOf="parent"
    app:layout_constraintRight_toRightOf="parent"
    app:errorTextAppearance="@style/ErrorText"
    app:errorEnabled="true">

    <com.google.android.material.textfield.TextInputEditText
        android:id="@+id/login_email_address_edit_text"
        android:layout_width="match_parent"
        android:layout_height="wrap_content"
        android:minHeight="@dimen/edit_text_min_height"
        android:inputType="textEmailAddress"
        android:hint="@string/login_email_address" />

</com.google.android.material.textfield.TextInputLayout>
```

'2022-04-15T18:30:51Z', 'closed_at': None, 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': 'Description: Hey, this task is a duplicate for [1775](https://github.com/material-components/material-components-android/issues/1775) since it was closed before resolving.

I have an issue with the newest alpha03 release. It is impossible to select AM hours when time format is set to TimeFormat.CLOCK_12, because there is no toggle or anything that will allow me to do so. Please see the following screenshot:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12632186/98636955-11d88a80-2328-11eb-8459-ff17478235e8.png)


Expected behavior: I would expect to be allowed to specify if a picked time is AM or PM.

Source code:
Picker initialization:

```
    val materialPicker = MaterialTimePicker.Builder()
            .setHour(12)
            .setMinute(0)
            .setInputMode(MaterialTimePicker.INPUT_MODE_CLOCK)
            .setTimeFormat(TimeFormat.CLOCK_12H)
            .build()
        materialPicker.addOnPositiveButtonClickListener {
            onTimePicked(materialPicker.hour, materialPicker.minute)
        }
        materialPicker.show(parentFragmentManager, null)
```

Style for the activity:

    <style name="DialogActivity" parent="Theme.MaterialComponents.Light.Dialog.Bridge">
        <item name="windowNoTitle">true</item>
        <item name="android:windowBackground">#ffffff</item>
        <item name="materialTimePickerTheme">
            @style/ThemeOverlay.MaterialComponents.Light
        </item>
    </style>
Android API version: Android 10 (SDK 29), also tested on Android Emulator with Android 5.1.1 (SDK 22)

Material Library version: Material Android Library version 1.3.0-alpha03

Device: Samsung Tab A 10,1 2019 (Android 10, SDK 29)', 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/material-components/material-components-android/issues/1863/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'timeline_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/material-components/material-components-android/issues/1863/timeline', 'performed_via_github_app': None}, 'comment': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/material-components/material-components-android/issues/comments/1100280881', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/material-components/material-components-android/issues/1863#issuecomment-1100280881', 'issue_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/material-components/material-components-android/issues/1863', 'id': 1100280881, 'node_id': 'IC_kwDOBII42M5BlPQx', 'user': {'login': 'drchen', 'id': 1092362, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjEwOTIzNjI=', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1092362?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/drchen', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/drchen', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/drchen/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/drchen/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/drchen/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/drchen/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/drchen/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/drchen/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/drchen/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/drchen/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/drchen/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'created_at': '2022-04-15T18:30:51Z', 'updated_at': '2022-04-15T18:30:51Z', 'author_association': 'CONTRIBUTOR', 'body': 'Just a note - Resolves https://github.com/material-components/material-components-android/issues/1855

fun createChip(): Chip {

    chip.chipEndPadding = 0F
    chip.textStartPadding = 0F
    chip.textEndPadding = 0F

}
```

'2022-04-15T17:58:02Z', 'closed_at': None, 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '**Description:** So I am currently using badges on tabs on a bottom navigation view in my activity. Like so: I occasionally get an `IllegalArgumentException` crash report in my Google Play Console. By reading the call stack you can trace the issue back to the `createParcelableBadgeStates()` function in [BadgeUtils.java](https://github.com/material-components/material-components-android/blob/master/lib/java/com/google/android/material/badge/BadgeUtils.java). ```java /** * Given a map of int keys to {@code BadgeDrawable BadgeDrawables}, creates a parcelable map of * unique int keys to {@code BadgeDrawable.SavedState SavedStates}. Useful for state restoration. * * @param badgeDrawables A {@link SparseArray} that contains a map of int keys (e.g. menuItemId) * to {@code BadgeDrawable BadgeDrawables}. * @return A parcelable {@link SparseArray} that contains a map of int keys (e.g. menuItemId) to * {@code BadgeDrawable.SavedState SavedStates}. */ @NonNull public static ParcelableSparseArray createParcelableBadgeStates( @NonNull SparseArray badgeDrawables) { ParcelableSparseArray badgeStates = new ParcelableSparseArray(); for (int i = 0; i < badgeDrawables.size(); i++) { int key = badgeDrawables.keyAt(i); BadgeDrawable badgeDrawable = badgeDrawables.valueAt(i); if (badgeDrawable == null) { throw new IllegalArgumentException("badgeDrawable cannot be null"); //<----- This is the error that is being thrown } badgeStates.put(key, badgeDrawable.getSavedState()); } return badgeStates; } ``` I have not been able to replicate it myself, but I was curious to see if anyone else knew about/had this issue because it does appear to be regularly occurring. **Full CallStack:** ***java.lang.IllegalArgumentException*** com.google.android.material.badge.BadgeUtils.createParcelableBadgeStates ``` java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: at com.google.android.material.badge.BadgeUtils.createParcelableBadgeStates (BadgeUtils.java:136) at 'closed_at': None, 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
I want the BottomNavigation and Snackbar to be displayed on the same screen. Also, for BottomNavigation's Behavior, I specify HideBottomViewOnScrollBehavior.

When I try to show the Snackbar by simply specifying HideBottomViewOnScrollBehavior for `app:layout_behavior`, the Snackbar is hidden behind the BottomNavigation as shown in the following recording.

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42328337/137682534-f5b9e297-43ea-48b5-b47b-5c77877d5d48.mp4

**Describe the solution you'd like**
As mentioned in [MATERIAL DESIGN](https://material.io/components/snackbars#placement), the Snackbar should be placed above the BottomNavigationView. I also want the Snackbar to move as the BottomNavigationView moves.
So, the ideal behavior would look like the following recording.

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42328337/137081304-ca30b197-0af3-4eaa-95a3-3b3ed0255db8.mp4

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
I have mentioned in [this issue](https://github.com/material-components/material-components-android/issues/2425) how to implement this behavior.
I can achieve the expected behavior by specifying Snackbar as the anchor for BottomNavigationView.
Here is the code I wrote. I create a custom behavior.

```kt
// kt
class CustomHideBottomViewBehavior(context: Context, attrs: AttributeSet) : HideBottomViewOnScrollBehavior<BottomNavigationView>(context, attrs) {

    // this value is the default margin for Snackbar.
    private val bottomMargin: Int = context.resources.getDimensionPixelSize(R.dimen.mtrl_snackbar_margin)

    override fun layoutDependsOn(parent: CoordinatorLayout, child: BottomNavigationView, dependency: View): Boolean {
        if (dependency is Snackbar.SnackbarLayout) {
            updateSnackbarPosition(child, dependency)
        }
        return super.layoutDependsOn(parent, child, dependency)
    }

    private fun updateSnackbarPosition(child: View, snackbarLayout: Snackbar.SnackbarLayout) {
        val params = snackbarLayout.layoutParams
        if (params is CoordinatorLayout.LayoutParams) {
            params.anchorId = child.id
            params.gravity = Gravity.TOP or Gravity.CENTER_HORIZONTAL
            params.anchorGravity = Gravity.TOP or Gravity.CENTER_HORIZONTAL
            params.bottomMargin = 0
            snackbarLayout.layoutParams = params
            snackbarLayout.translationY = -bottomMargin.toFloat()
        }
    }
}
```

```xml
<!-- xml -->
<com.google.android.material.bottomnavigation.BottomNavigationView
    android:id="@+id/bottomNavView"
    android:layout_width="match_parent"
    android:layout_height="@dimen/bottom_nav_height"
    android:layout_gravity="bottom"
    app:layout_behavior="CustomHideBottomViewBehavior"
    />
```

In this code, I can't use `Snackbar.setAnchorView()` method, so we use the `CoordinatorLayout.LayoutParams.setAnchorId()`.
I would like to see that the SDK will be implemented in such a way that this behavior can be achieved without creating a custom behavior.

**Additional context**
Ideally, it would be nice if Snackbar could automatically find anchors for BottomNavigation, FAB, etc.

'author_association': 'CONTRIBUTOR', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '**Description:**
Not always but very often, the thumb and its surrounding "holo" circle flickers when moving the thumb to the start or the end of the slider. See this gif:

![sldier-flickering](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3776997/77520542-a5387a80-6e81-11ea-8f6e-e17f1f4ef6ad.gif)


**Expected behavior:** No flickering should occur.

**Source code:**

```xml
        <com.google.android.material.slider.Slider
            android:id="@+id/slider"
            android:layout_width="match_parent"
            android:layout_height="wrap_content"
            android:layout_marginTop="10dp"
            android:value="20"
            android:valueFrom="5.0"
            android:valueTo="100.0"
            app:labelBehavior="gone"
            app:trackColorActive="@color/icon_primary"
            app:trackColorInactive="@color/ui_dark" />
```

**Android API version:** 28

**Material Library version:** 1.2.0-alpha05

**Device:** Samsung A70, OnePlus 5

'description': ''}], 'state': 'closed', 'locked': False, 'assignee': None, 'assignees': [], 'milestone': None, 'comments': 1, 'created_at': '2020-11-01T00:55:46Z', 'updated_at': '2022-04-14T23:55:12Z', 'closed_at': '2022-04-14T23:55:12Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '**Description:** 
`MaterialTextView` supports the ability to read and apply line height from TextAppearance but it doesn't apply firstBaselineToTopHeight & lastBaselineToBottomHeight.

**Expected behavior:**
I noticed the height of my view was only `16dp` when I had a single line of text but `36dp` when I had two lines and plus `20dp` for each line after. After some debugging I noticed that `firstBaselineToTopHeight` and `lastBaselineToBottomHeight` are only ever applied if you use them as styles and `lineHeight` is the distance between two baselines so it does nothing if there is only a single line of text. 

When using the following code.

```xml
// Styles
<style name="MyApp.AppTheme" parent="Theme.MaterialComponents.DayNight">
  ..
  <item name="textAppearanceBody2">@style/TextAppearance.MyApp.Body2</item>
</style>

<style name="TextAppearance.MyApp.Body2" parent="TextAppearance.MaterialComponents.Body2">
  <item name="android:textColor">?colorOnBackground</item>
  <item name="android:textSize">14sp</item>
  <item name="lineHeight">20sp</item>
  <item name="firstBaselineToTopHeight">15sp</item>
  <item name="lastBaselineToBottomHeight">5sp</item>
</style>

// View
<com.google.android.material.textview.MaterialTextView
  android:textAppearance="?textAppearanceBody2"  .. />
```

The whole purpose of the `MaterialTextView` is to have more elegant looking text but it's pretty much useless unless that text is multi-line.

It should be fairly easy to apply `firstBaselineToTopHeight` and `lastBaselineToBottomHeight` as there is already logic to add the line height by reading it from the text appearance.

https://github.com/material-components/material-components-android/blob/f945a0649b9cddc13afafeb80df7218f1aa85ef8/lib/java/com/google/android/material/textview/MaterialTextView.java#L103', 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/material-components/material-components-android/issues/1848/reactions', 'total_count': 1, '+1': 1, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'timeline_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/material-components/material-components-android/issues/1848/timeline', 'performed_via_github_app': None}}

'2022-04-14T23:55:12Z', 'updated_at': '2022-04-14T23:55:12Z', 'author_association': 'CONTRIBUTOR', 'body': "Hi given that `firstBaselineToTopHeight` and `lastBaselineToBottomHeight` are not part of standard text appearance attributes and Material typography system is not using them, I'm afraid that we will be very reluctant to add them. (We did add the support of `lineHeight` with text appearance but `lineHeight` is much more frequently used and we need to consider about the maintenance cost of adding more non-standard attributes.)

You can still use `firstBaselineToTopHeight` and `lastBaselineToBottomHeight` in your component style or by overriding `?attr/textViewStyle`. So I'll close this issue as won't do. '2020-02-05T17:58:54Z', 'updated_at': '2022-04-14T20:39:12Z', 'closed_at': '2022-04-14T20:39:12Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '**Description:** Calling `View.getDrawableState` on a `MaterialButton` within an `OnAttachStateChangeListener` computes a new drawable state without notifying `drawableStateChanged`. This results in the `MaterialButton` failing to update the drawable state of the background tint until the next time it changes (by e.g. touching the button, etc). `getDrawableState` is used by many APIs - something as simple as `setTextColor` will call `getDrawableState` and expose the problem. **Expected behavior:** I have created a sample project that demonstrates the problem [here](https://github.com/damianw/WasclDrawableStateIssue). In the following demo, we attach a fragment (defined in [`MainFragment`](https://github.com/damianw/WasclDrawableStateIssue/blob/master/app/src/main/java/wtf/log/wascldrawablestateissue/MainFragment.kt)) at some point after the activity (defined in [`MainActivity`](https://github.com/damianw/WasclDrawableStateIssue/blob/master/app/src/main/java/wtf/log/wascldrawablestateissue/MainActivity.kt)) is created, and while the window has focus. The background tint of the button (defined in [`button_tint_selector`](https://github.com/damianw/WasclDrawableStateIssue/blob/master/app/src/main/res/color/button_tint_selector.xml)) defines the disabled state as red with a default state of green. The background tint incorrectly displays the disabled state even though the button is in the enabled state. Touching the button (or un-focusing and re-focusing the window, etc) synchronizes the state to the background tint and the issue resolves itself. **Source code:** https://github.com/damianw/WasclDrawableStateIssue **Android API version:** Any (28 in demo) **Material Library version:** 1.2.0-alpha04 **Device:** Any (Pixel 3 simulator in demo)', 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/material-components/material-components-android/issues/982/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'timeline_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/material-components/material-components-android/issues/982/timeline', 'performed_via_github_app': None}}

'comments': 11, 'created_at': '2019-12-19T17:17:52Z', 'updated_at': '2022-04-14T20:26:02Z', 'closed_at': '2022-04-14T20:26:02Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '**Description:** When using a MaterialButton with fixed width and fixed number of text lines, I tried to find a way to deal with dynamic button text that could be too long for the button size. When the text is too long for the button the words that don't fit will simply not be displayed by default, thus not indicating that there are words missing. When setting "ellipsize" to "end" the three dots get displayed, but the beginning of the text will be cut off in some situations.

**Steps to reproduce:** Check out and run this sample project: [https://github.com/geworfener/MaterialButtonEllipsizeBug](url)

Alternatively:
1. Create a new Android project with a single activity.
2. Add material lib and set material theme.
3. Use the following activity layout:
```<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
    xmlns:app="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res-auto"
    xmlns:tools="http://schemas.android.com/tools"
    android:layout_width="match_parent"
    android:layout_height="match_parent"
    tools:context=".MainActivity">

    <com.google.android.material.button.MaterialButton
        android:layout_width="128dp"
        android:layout_height="wrap_content"
        android:maxLines="2"
        android:ellipsize="end"
        android:text="Hello world, this is a long text!"
        app:layout_constraintBottom_toBottomOf="parent"
        app:layout_constraintLeft_toLeftOf="parent"
        app:layout_constraintRight_toRightOf="parent"
        app:layout_constraintTop_toTopOf="parent" />

</androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout>
```

**Actual behavior:** 

The first letter of the second text line gets cut off.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6763984/71192737-28e23a00-2289-11ea-933e-08fe8950997b.png)


**Expected behavior:** All words of the text are displayed fully.

**Android API version:** 28

**Material Library version:** 1.1.0-beta02, 1.2.0-alpha02

**Device:** Pixel 3a XL

'comments': 11, 'created_at': '2019-12-19T17:17:52Z', 'updated_at': '2022-04-14T20:26:02Z', 'closed_at': '2022-04-14T20:26:02Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '**Description:** When using a MaterialButton with fixed width and fixed number of text lines, I tried to find a way to deal with dynamic button text that could be too long for the button size. When the text is too long for the button the words that don't fit will simply not be displayed by default, thus not indicating that there are words missing. When setting "ellipsize" to "end" the three dots get displayed, but the beginning of the text will be cut off in some situations.

**Steps to reproduce:** Check out and run this sample project: [https://github.com/geworfener/MaterialButtonEllipsizeBug](url)

Alternatively:
1. Create a new Android project with a single activity.
2. Add material lib and set material theme.
3. Use the following activity layout:
```<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
    xmlns:app="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res-auto"
    xmlns:tools="http://schemas.android.com/tools"
    android:layout_width="match_parent"
    android:layout_height="match_parent"
    tools:context=".MainActivity">

    <com.google.android.material.button.MaterialButton
        android:layout_width="128dp"
        android:layout_height="wrap_content"
        android:maxLines="2"
        android:ellipsize="end"
        android:text="Hello world, this is a long text!"
        app:layout_constraintBottom_toBottomOf="parent"
        app:layout_constraintLeft_toLeftOf="parent"
        app:layout_constraintRight_toRightOf="parent"
        app:layout_constraintTop_toTopOf="parent" />

</androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout>
```

**Actual behavior:** 

The first letter of the second text line gets cut off.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6763984/71192737-28e23a00-2289-11ea-933e-08fe8950997b.png)


**Expected behavior:** All words of the text are displayed fully.

**Android API version:** 28

**Material Library version:** 1.1.0-beta02, 1.2.0-alpha02

**Device:** Pixel 3a XL

#### Don't forget:

- [x] Identify the component the PR relates to in brackets in the title.

- [x] Link to GitHub issues it solves. `closes #1234`
- [x] Sign the CLA bot. You can do this once the pull request is opened.

[Contributing](https://github.com/material-components/material-components-android/blob/master/docs/contributing.md)
has more information and tips for a great pull request.

'2022-04-14T18:49:56Z', 'closed_at': '2022-04-14T18:49:56Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '**Description:** Setting a non-opaque background tint (via `setBackgroundTintList`) on a `MaterialButton` causes the new background tint to blend with the previous background tint, rather than replace it. This is especially noticeable when trying to set a transparent background tint, which has no effect. **Source code:** A sample app that reproduces the problem can be found here: https://github.com/damianw/MaterialButtonTransparentTint **Expected behavior:** In the following demo ([MainActivity](https://github.com/damianw/MaterialButtonTransparentTint/blob/master/app/src/main/java/wtf/log/materialbuttontransparenttint/MainActivity.kt), [activity_main.xml](https://github.com/damianw/MaterialButtonTransparentTint/blob/master/app/src/main/res/layout/activity_main.xml)), we define a `MaterialButton` like so: ```xml ``` and change the background tint whenever the button is pressed: ```kotlin class MainActivity : AppCompatActivity() { private var color = Color.RED override fun onCreate(savedInstanceState: Bundle?) { super.onCreate(savedInstanceState) setContentView(R.layout.activity_main) val button: AppCompatButton = findViewById(R.id.button) button.setOnClickListener { // does not appear at all val altColor = 0x00000000 // blends with red, result is purple // val altColor = 0x660000FF val nextColor = if (color == Color.RED) altColor else Color.RED button.backgroundTintList = ColorStateList.valueOf(nextColor) color = nextColor } } } ``` As seen in the demonstration below, clicking the button has no effect: The issue appears to be that the new color is actually blended with the previous color - an effect that can be confirmed by changing `altColor` to `0x660000FF` (translucent blue). In this demonstration, the new color is purple: This issue is not present when with either `android.widget.Button` or `androidx.appcompat.widget.AppCompatButton`. Using an `altColor` of `0x00000000` on an `androidx.appcompat.widget.AppCompatButton`: Using an `altColor` of `0x660000FF` (translucent blue) on an `androidx.appcompat.widget.AppCompatButton`: **Android API version:** 29 **Material Library version:** `com.google.android.material:material:1.2.0-alpha04` **Device:** API 29 Emulator', 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/material-components/material-components-android/issues/1033/reactions', 'total_count': 3, '+1': 3, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'timeline_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/material-components/material-components-android/issues/1033/timeline', 'performed_via_github_app': None}}

'2022-04-13T01:50:49Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '**Description:** 

[Exposed Dropdown Menu](https://github.com/material-components/material-components-android/blob/master/docs/components/TextField.md#implementing-an-exposed-dropdown-menu) doesn't show items after user selection and fragment transition.

Following is the basic xml declaration:

    <com.google.android.material.textfield.TextInputLayout
        ...
        style="@style/Widget.MaterialComponents.TextInputLayout.OutlinedBox.ExposedDropdownMenu"
     
             <AutoCompleteTextView
                .... 
                android:id="@+id/dropdown"
                android:dropDownHeight="300dp"
                android:inputType="none" />
    </com.google.android.material.textfield.TextInputLayout>

And, the declared code on the fragment (inside `onViewCreated()`):

        val items = listOf("Material", "Design", "Components", "Android")
        val adapter = ArrayAdapter(requireContext(), R.layout.item_menu, items)
        dropdown.setAdapter(adapter)
        dropdown.setText(items[0], false)

As mentioned [here](https://material.io/components/menus/android#exposed-dropdown-menus), it was set on `AutoCompleteTextView's` _setText_ method  (_dropdown.setText("", false)_) the filter parameter as false. However, after navigating to a next fragment and coming back to it, only the pre-selected text is shown on the dropdown.

Fragments are changed using [navigation component](https://developer.android.com/guide/navigation) (v. `2.3.2`).

**Expected behavior:** Dropdown should show all items.

**Android API version:** `Android API 30`

**Material Library version:** `1.3.0-rc01`

{'push_id': 9598643099, 'size': 1, 'distinct_size': 1, 'ref': 'refs/heads/master', 'head': 'b6b895a1e40efbf2e36b2ea5e91bae7bcd0bdb8c', 'before': '05be1b92c5720e4c6c6f42f93918bd6554099625', 'commits': [{'sha': 'b6b895a1e40efbf2e36b2ea5e91bae7bcd0bdb8c', 'author': {'email': 'conradchen@google.com', 'name': 'conradchen'}, 'message': "[Button] Fix icon textStart/End alignment with multiline text

When calculating text width to decide the icon position with textStart/End alignment, we missed accounting for multiline text. Fixes this by calculating each line's width separately and take the widest one to decide the icon position.

Resolves https://github.com/material-components/material-components-android/issues/2007

{'push_id': 9597979280, 'size': 1, 'distinct_size': 1, 'ref': 'refs/heads/master', 'head': '05be1b92c5720e4c6c6f42f93918bd6554099625', 'before': 'b8e1f978940c218502ee6161d0b3f673299eceb0', 'commits': [{'sha': '05be1b92c5720e4c6c6f42f93918bd6554099625', 'author': {'email': 'conradchen@google.com', 'name': 'conradchen'}, 'message': "[TopAppBar] Fix app:expanded=false not working

When an AppBarLayout is loaded, it will load the attribute and set up a non-forcing pending action. However when it's measured, the current scroll state will be saved and restored, which will override the non-forcing pending action. This behavior is incorrect - if there's a pending action, we shouldn't restore the scrolling state because it's meant to be changed.

Resolves https://github.com/material-components/material-components-android/issues/2629

'2022-04-11T19:41:21Z', 'closed_at': '2022-04-11T19:41:21Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': 'I'm currently trying out the new Material 3 features using `com.google.android.material:material:1.5.0` and I'm pretty pleased with the results so far. Good job!

However there's one thing that keeps bugging me in this process: The documentation is not easy to follow!

When browsing the Material 2 documentation on material.io on every page on the top the site wants me to check out Material 3. Once I click on the link and I'm redirected to me.material.io I get to the "correct"/up-to-date documentation, which is a lot shorter. Some parts  even reference the "old" Material 2 documentation and it is not clear where Material 2 documentation still applies and where Material 3 superseded the previous recommendations. So I've been going back and forth a lotto try and figure out how the stuff works I need for my app.

There's one particular thing I haven't been able to find out though. If you look at the page for the ["Top app bar"](https://m3.material.io/components/top-app-bar/overview) it proudly presents the differences between Material 2 and 3 where now the transition between the Status bar and the App bar is seamless and uses the same colour. Curiously a lot of example figures use this M3 design but sometimes just the M2 variant is shown without any explanation why it suddenly is the "old" version. The [codelab](https://codelabs.developers.google.com/codelabs/apply-dynamic-color) guide for example doesn't use M3-style status/app bar at all it's always a 2 colored variant there. The [Material Theme builder](https://material-foundation.github.io/material-theme-builder/#/dynamic) which is indirectly referenced by this guide does make use of this does use the M3-style.

By following the code examples in the documentation, I always get an app that has a different colour for the status bar (the primary colour) on a Virtual Android device with Android 12.

So I come to the conclusion that there must be one, or a combination of the following problems:
1. The documentation is incomplete and doesn't contain the required piece of information to make this happen
2. There is an error on my side and I missed an (obvious) step and/or the docmentation is poorly structured for this particular topic
3. MCA doesn't support this feature yet (even though the documentation suggests otherwise)

I'd be happy if you could help me complete the puzzle, most likely there is some sort of communication error somewhere, leading to the disconnect.', 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/material-components/material-components-android/issues/2626/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'timeline_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/material-components/material-components-android/issues/2626/timeline', 'performed_via_github_app': None}}

{'push_id': 9597719389, 'size': 1, 'distinct_size': 1, 'ref': 'refs/heads/master', 'head': '19d05000bcc273f781a85ce41530f604fead268e', 'before': 'dc0d8a956e12c0c44b1cec8e6438fbe71debb3c4', 'commits': [{'sha': '19d05000bcc273f781a85ce41530f604fead268e', 'author': {'email': 'conradchen@google.com', 'name': 'conradchen'}, 'message': '[Button] Fix icon position with multiline text

When the icon gravity is textTop, we are using the smaller one of the calculated height from text paint and the text layout height to decide the icon position. This is wrong when there are multiple lines of text since the text paint is always single line and always shorter than the actual height.

Fixes this by returning the actual layout height whenever there are multiple lines of text to fix the issue.

Resolves https://github.com/material-components/material-components-android/issues/2619

PiperOrigin-RevId: 440923733', 'distinct': True, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/material-components/material-components-android/commits/19d05000bcc273f781a85ce41530f604fead268e'}]}

'2022-04-11T19:14:36Z', 'closed_at': '2022-04-11T19:14:36Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '**Description:** 
Given the iconGravity is textTop
When text have multiple lines (example: button have constrained width, but text is longer or user have bigger font scale)
Then icon is wrongly laid out on the text
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11424422/160372041-75f1ce48-b58d-49e8-ad52-b799c810d1c6.png)


**Expected behavior:** 
Button should take in account the number of lines when calculating icon vertical position in textTop mode

**Source code:** 
```
        <com.google.android.material.button.MaterialButton
            android:layout_width="100dp"
            android:layout_height="wrap_content"
            android:layout_centerInParent="true"
            android:text="some longer text 4lines"
            android:textSize="14sp"
            app:iconPadding="10dp"
            app:icon="@android:drawable/ic_menu_delete"
            app:iconGravity="textTop" />
```

**Minimal sample app repro:** n/d

**Android API version:** Android 10

**Material Library version:** 1.6.0-alpha03, 1.6.0-beta1

**Device:** emulator, Xiaomi Redmi Note 4

'2022-04-11T18:38:43Z', 'closed_at': '2022-04-11T15:28:52Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': 'Does Material3 support `TextInputLayout` I have tried it but not working correctly and looks like it still uses Material 2.

using `Widget.MaterialComponents.TextInputLayout.OutlinedBox` as a parent works with `shapeAppearance`
using `Widget.Material3.TextInputLayout.OutlinedBox` as a parent is not working (no effect) with `shapeAppearance`

```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<resources>
    <style name="AppTextInputLayout" parent="Widget.MaterialComponents.TextInputLayout.OutlinedBox">
        <item name="materialThemeOverlay">@style/ThemeOverlay.App.TextInputLayout</item>
        <item name="shapeAppearance">@style/ShapeAppearance.App.SmallComponent</item>
    </style>

    <style name="ThemeOverlay.App.TextInputLayout" parent="">
        <!-- Outline, hint floating, and cursor color -->
        <item name="colorPrimary">@color/primaryAccent</item>
        <!-- Text color -->
        <item name="colorOnSurface">@color/primaryWhite</item>
        <item name="colorError">@android:color/holo_red_light</item>
        <item name="editTextStyle">@style/Widget.Material3.TextInputEditText.OutlinedBox</item>
    </style>
</resources>

Using it like this
```
<style name="Theme.App" parent="Theme.Material3.DayNight">
   <item name="textInputStyle">@style/AppTextInputLayout</item>
</style>
```

I have a custom TabLayout style in my theme:

```xml
<style name="BaseAppTheme" parent="Theme.MaterialComponents.Light.NoActionBar">
    <item name="tabStyle">@style/Widget.AppTheme.TabLayout</item>
</style>
<style name="Widget.AppTheme.TabLayout" parent="Widget.MaterialComponents.TabLayout">
  <item name="tabTextAppearance">@style/TextAppearance.AppTheme.Body</item>
  <item name="tabTextColor">?android:attr/textColorSecondary</item>
  <item name="tabSelectedTextColor">?attr/colorOnPrimary</item>
</style>
```
Notice it has a text appearance which uses custom ttf font I provided with the app. For this example I have set it to some exotic font. Font-family xml is at the end of this message.

I'll provide a screenshots and will annotate them below:

1. Here we see the first issue: **Selected tab doesn't use bold version of my custom font** although it is provided in the font family. Instead, it uses Roboto, which is the default system font
![screen1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42920/73548512-9321f900-4449-11ea-8c45-5883a213255a.png)

2. Now I switch to another tab and we can see that **first tab's font is reset back to Roboto** too!
![screen2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42920/73548518-96b58000-4449-11ea-97e1-a92b7889b1ac.png)

3. Now I switch back to first tab and the **last tab's font is replaced with Roboto**. It was correct one in the beginning.
![screen3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42920/73548521-99b07080-4449-11ea-85fc-56d318af8bd0.png)

So each time I switch to some tab, its font is lost.

**Expected behavior:**
1. Font is not being reset on tab switch
2. Selected tab font uses weighted variant of the font from the font-family

**Android API version:** API 25

**Material Library version:** `1.1.0-rc01`

**Device:** Android Emulator API 25

Here's the font-family resource I used for this demo:

```xml
<font-family xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
  xmlns:app="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res-auto"
  xmlns:tools="http://schemas.android.com/tools"
  tools:ignore="UnusedAttribute">
  <!-- How use and set fonts see wiki page "Fonts In Xml". -->

  <font
    android:font="@font/uncial_antiqua"
    android:fontStyle="normal"
    android:fontWeight="400"
    app:font="@font/uncial_antiqua"
    app:fontStyle="normal"
    app:fontWeight="400" />

  <font
    android:font="@font/uncial_antiqua_bold"
    android:fontStyle="normal"
    android:fontWeight="700"
    app:font="@font/uncial_antiqua_bold"
    app:fontStyle="normal"
    app:fontWeight="700" />

</font-family>

To use M3 text input layout styles, you need to change your AppTextInputLayout to inherit from Widget.Material3.TextInputLayout.OutlinedBox. To apply custom share appearance, you need to override `shapeAppearanceOverlay`, instead of `shapeAppearance`.

'closed_at': None, 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '**Description:** https://github.com/material-components/material-components-android/tree/master/catalog/java/io/material/catalog/bottomappbar
The BottomSheet (#3b3b3b) is too light (the elevation of BottomSheet is 32dp totally).

![Screenshot_20210908-145455](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/71050561/132454477-7cd5c134-ce41-4dd2-a847-239b020092cf.png)


**Expected behavior:** The BottomSheet should be #2d2d2d (the elevation of BottomSheet should be 16dp).
https://material.io/design/environment/elevation.html
https://material.io/design/color/dark-theme.html

**Source code:** https://github.com/material-components/material-components-android/blob/master/catalog/java/io/material/catalog/bottomappbar/res/layout/cat_bottomappbar_fragment.xml#L49
(original)
```
  <FrameLayout
      android:id="@+id/bottom_drawer"
      android:layout_width="match_parent"
      android:layout_height="wrap_content"
      android:elevation="16dp"                                                                <=
      app:behavior_hideable="true"
      app:layout_behavior="@string/bottom_sheet_behavior">

    <com.google.android.material.navigation.NavigationView
        android:id="@+id/navigation_view"
        android:layout_width="match_parent"
        android:layout_height="wrap_content"
        app:menu="@menu/demo_primary"/>
  </FrameLayout>
```
(revised)
```
  <FrameLayout
      android:id="@+id/bottom_drawer"
      android:layout_width="match_parent"
      android:layout_height="wrap_content"
      app:behavior_hideable="true"
      app:layout_behavior="@string/bottom_sheet_behavior">

    <com.google.android.material.navigation.NavigationView
        android:id="@+id/navigation_view"
        android:layout_width="match_parent"
        android:layout_height="wrap_content"
        app:menu="@menu/demo_primary"/>
  </FrameLayout>
```

'2022-04-08T15:02:32Z', 'closed_at': '2022-04-08T15:02:32Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '**Description:**
When using  `MaterialShapeDrawable.createWithElevationOverlay()` and adding it as the background to a view, it doesn't apply the semi-transparent overlay to indicate elevation if `colorOnSurface` is a color state list resource.

The test app has a night theme with `colorOnSurface` reference to a color state list resource that is used to set the alpha on a color:
```
<selector xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android">
    <item android:alpha="0.87" android:color="#fff" />
</selector>
```
There are 2 TextViews and they both have a MaterialShapeDrawable set as their background. The second one uses a theme overlay to illustrate the elevation overlay working with an argb color set as `colorOnSurface`.

```
<style name="ThemeOverlay.App.White87ARGB" parent="ThemeOverlay.MaterialComponents">
    <item name="colorOnSurface">#DEFFFFFF</item>
</style>
```

**Expected behavior:**
The background of `colorOnSurface: @color/white_87` should match `colorOnSurface: #DEFFFFFF`.

![Screenshot_1580244947](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3336370/73304722-a6289500-41cd-11ea-9c29-5359796fbc70.png)

**Source code:** 
[https://github.com/claytongreen/elevation_overlay_bug](https://github.com/claytongreen/elevation_overlay_bug)

**Android API version:** 29

**Material Library version:** 1.2.0-alpha04

**Device:** API 29 Pixel 3 emulator

'2022-04-08T14:10:46Z', 'closed_at': '2022-04-05T19:38:33Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '**Description:** https://github.com/material-components/material-components-android/tree/master/catalog/java/io/material/catalog/bottomappbar
The BottomSheet (#3b3b3b) is too light (the elevation of BottomSheet is 32dp totally).

![Screenshot_20210908-145455](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/71050561/132454477-7cd5c134-ce41-4dd2-a847-239b020092cf.png)


**Expected behavior:** The BottomSheet should be #2d2d2d (the elevation of BottomSheet should be 16dp).
https://material.io/design/environment/elevation.html
https://material.io/design/color/dark-theme.html

**Source code:** https://github.com/material-components/material-components-android/blob/master/catalog/java/io/material/catalog/bottomappbar/res/layout/cat_bottomappbar_fragment.xml
(original)
```
  <FrameLayout
      android:id="@+id/bottom_drawer"
      android:layout_width="match_parent"
      android:layout_height="wrap_content"
      android:elevation="16dp"                                                                <=
      app:behavior_hideable="true"
      app:layout_behavior="@string/bottom_sheet_behavior">

    <com.google.android.material.navigation.NavigationView
        android:id="@+id/navigation_view"
        android:layout_width="match_parent"
        android:layout_height="wrap_content"
        app:menu="@menu/demo_primary"/>
  </FrameLayout>
```
(revised)
```
  <FrameLayout
      android:id="@+id/bottom_drawer"
      android:layout_width="match_parent"
      android:layout_height="wrap_content"
      app:behavior_hideable="true"
      app:layout_behavior="@string/bottom_sheet_behavior">

    <com.google.android.material.navigation.NavigationView
        android:id="@+id/navigation_view"
        android:layout_width="match_parent"
        android:layout_height="wrap_content"
        app:menu="@menu/demo_primary"/>
  </FrameLayout>
```

**Android API version:** 23

**Material Library version:** 1.4.0

{'push_id': 9565830627, 'size': 1, 'distinct_size': 1, 'ref': 'refs/heads/master', 'head': 'c6a654c7dd68827a55d6d3dcda424cf6749678fa', 'before': '139f35cbc87d1303b5b4b021025f35df2c2f3775', 'commits': [{'sha': 'c6a654c7dd68827a55d6d3dcda424cf6749678fa', 'author': {'email': 'conradchen@google.com', 'name': 'conradchen'}, 'message': '[DatePicker] Fix edge-to-edge mode being applied multiple times

When the date picker goes back from background to foreground, the onStart() method will be called and make enableEdgeToEdge() be called again. This will make it incorrectly use the header height and top padding already adjusted with system inset as the original height and padding, and thus add the inset multiple times.

Creates a flag to only enable edge-to-edge once to fix the issue.

Resolves https://github.com/material-components/material-components-android/issues/2628

override fun onViewCreated(view: View, savedInstanceState: Bundle?) {

            dateRangePicker.show(childFragmentManager, "materialDatePicker")
        }
}

None, 'body': 'I was using Material design 1.1.0 .

For tabs with viewpager2 I updated it to '1.2.0-alpha05' Material library version it was working fine for single module but was crashing for another module where I've developed my custom material designed TextInputLayout. I changed theme from 'Theme.AppCompat.Light.NoActionBar' to Theme.MaterialComponents.Light.NoActionBar and crash fixed. After fixing crash and upgrading theme it is showing me white floating label , buttons , indiators etc.

old file had conflict with material while using `AppCompact `with `parent="Widget.MaterialComponents.TextInputLayout.OutlinedBox.Dense"` after updating to `1.2.0-alpha05` it was resolved but style background is not working now.


```

        <item name="android:textColor">@color/label_title_black</item>
        <item name="android:textSize">@dimen/title_heading_12sp</item>
        <item name="android:background">@android:color/transparent</item>
        <item name="colorControlNormal">@color/label_title_black</item>
        <item name="colorControlHighlight">@color/label_title_black</item>
        <item name="colorControlActivated">@color/label_title_black</item>

    </style>

  <style name="material_edit_text" parent="Widget.AppCompat.EditText">
        <item name="android:paddingStart">50dp</item>
        <item name="android:paddingLeft">50dp</item>
        <item name="android:background">@null</item>
        <item name="android:textSize">16sp</item>
    </style>

    <style name="error_label" parent="TextAppearance.Design.Hint">
        <item name="android:textSize">0sp</item>
        <item name="android:textColor">@color/red</item>
        <item name="android:visibility">gone</item>
    </style>

  <style name="BtnCustomStyle">
        <item name="android:background">@drawable/btn_confirm_selector</item>
        <item name="android:textColor">@android:color/white</item>
        <item name="android:textSize">15dp</item>
        <item name="android:layout_width">match_parent</item>
        <item name="android:layout_height">46dp</item>
        <item name="android:layout_marginStart">10dp</item>
        <item name="android:layout_marginEnd">10dp</item>
        <item name="android:textAllCaps">false</item>
        <item name="android:foreground">android:attr/selectableItemBackground</item>
    </style>

```

'updated_at': '2022-04-06T18:37:00Z', 'closed_at': '2022-04-06T18:37:00Z', 'author_association': 'CONTRIBUTOR', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': "**Description:**
Passing `defStyleRes` doesn't behave as expected; attributes inside this style resource are ignored.

This is because this constructor chains up to the 3-arg AppCompatTextView constructor (the 4 arg one doesn't exist there), meaning the `defStyleRes` is only used to resolve `android:lineHeight` / `lineHeight`.

The consequence is that for folks who are updating from `TextView` to `MaterialTextView` then there's a massive behavior change.

**Expected behavior:**

If the 4-arg constructor is called with 0 as the value for `defStyleAttr` (or where the theme doesn't define `textViewStyle`), then the passed style resource should be treated as the default style.

```kotlin
class MyCustomTextView(context: Context, attrs: AttributeSet) :
    MaterialTextView(context, attrs, 0, R.style.Widget_Demo_MyCustomTextView)
```

**Suggest**

Deprecating this 4-arg constructor. It doesn't make sense until AppCompatTextView supports it too.

Alternatively, add a lint check which will flag usage of this constructor as an error if the passed style contains anything except `android:lineHeight` or `lineHeight`.

**Android API version:** 
n/a

**Material Library version:**
1.1.0, current alpha too

**Device:**
n/a", 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/material-components/material-components-android/issues/1397/reactions', 'total_count': 2, '+1': 2, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'timeline_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/material-components/material-components-android/issues/1397/timeline', 'performed_via_github_app': None}}

Label is disappearing

**Source code:** 
```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
    xmlns:app="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res-auto"
    xmlns:tools="http://schemas.android.com/tools"
    android:layout_width="match_parent"
    android:layout_height="match_parent"
    android:paddingTop="80dp"
    tools:context=".MainActivity">

    <com.google.android.material.slider.RangeSlider
        android:id="@+id/amountSlider"
        android:layout_width="match_parent"
        android:layout_height="wrap_content"
        android:stepSize="1"
        android:valueFrom="0.0"
        android:valueTo="100.0"
        app:values="@array/initial_slider_values"
        tools:ignore="MissingConstraints" />

</androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout>
```

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/72196651/161275659-6fb550ac-eb45-4497-b7d8-b0d76aca45ea.png)

**Material Library version:** 1.5.0 (also tried 1.6.0-beta01)
